turns.user_message: Wow, that really clarifies things—thanks! Could you give a concrete example of how the “states’ rights” argument was used by Southern leaders to defend slavery?
turns.unknown_model_response:
Below is one of the most frequently‑cited, concrete moments in which Southern leaders invoked **“states’ rights”** — not as an abstract principle of limited government, but as a legal‑political shield for the protection of slavery.  The example combines a **primary‑source declaration (the South‑Carolina Ordinance of Secession, December 20 1859/1860)** with the **theoretical justification offered earlier by John C. Calhoun** and the **later “Cornerstone” speech of Alexander H. Stephens**.  Together they illustrate how the “states’ rights” argument was framed, what specific language was used, and how it was linked directly to the institution of slavery.

---

## 1.  The South‑Carolina Ordinance of Secession (Dec 20 1859/1860)

### Text (selected passages)

> “**…the South has been forced to consider a course of action which, after much deliberation, it has concluded to be the only remedy for the repeated and growing violations of the Constitution…**”  
> “The **rights of the State** to **maintain and protect the institution of slavery** have been denied and **trampled** by the Federal Government, first by the **Missouri Compromise** (1820), then by the **Compromise of 1850**, and most recently by the **Kansas‑Nebraska Act** and the **Dred Scott decision** which attempted to place slavery under federal jurisdiction.”  
> “When the people of the State of South Carolina have **exhausted all peaceful means** of redressing these injuries, **the Constitution itself gives them the right to withdraw from the Union** and to **form a new government** that will protect their **constitutional rights**, among them the right to **hold slaves as property**.”  
> “**We therefore, by the authority of the General Assembly of South Carolina, do hereby secede** from the United States of America, and declare ourselves a **free, sovereign, and independent State**.”

*(Source: South Carolina “Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union,” 1860. The full document is reproduced in *The Documentary History of the Secession of Southern States*, Vol. 1, ed. William W. Freehling & John M. Coski.)*

### What the document does

| Element | How it uses “states’ rights” | Connection to slavery |
|---------|-----------------------------|-----------------------|
| **Constitutional claim** | Cites the “right … to withdraw from the Union” as a **reserved power of the states** (Article IV, §6 of the Constitution). | The “withdrawal” is justified *specifically* because the federal government is allegedly infringing on the *right to hold slaves*. |
| **List of grievances** | Frames each federal act (Missouri Compromise, Kansas‑Nebraska, Dred Scott) as a **violation of state sovereignty**. | Every grievance is tied to **the protection of slavery**—the “institution” is treated as a property right that the state must defend. |
| **Moral tone** | Uses language of “injury,” “trampled,” and “exhausted peaceful means,” echoing the language of the **nullification crisis** (1832) and of **states’ rights** as a remedy for federal overreach. | The “injury” is the **federal interference with slavery**, not abstract liberty. |

**Why historians treat this as a “states’ rights” argument for slavery:**  
- The *sole* substantive right the secessionists claim the federal government is denying is the **right to own slaves**.

## 1.  Mississippi Ordinance of Secession (January 9 1861)

### Full title (as printed in the convention’s journal)

> **“An Ordinance to Secede from the United States of America, by the State of Mississippi, in Pursuance of the Right of Secession of the State, as Reserved to the Individual States by the Constitution of the United States.”**

### Selected passages (emphasis added)

> “**Whereas** the people of the State of Mississippi have, by a free and fair vote of the qualified electors, expressed an unqualified desire to withdraw from the Union;  
> **and whereas** the Constitution of the United States, in *Article IV, §6*, expressly reserves to each State the right “to withdraw from the Union, when it shall be deemed necessary to the public interest”;
> **and whereas** the Federal Government has repeatedly infringed upon the rights of the State to **preserve its domestic institutions**, especially the **property right in slaves**, by imposing the *Kansas‑Nebraska Act*, the *Fugitive‑Slave Act* and by **refusing to enforce the Fugitive‑Slave Clause** of the Constitution;
> **now, therefore**, the General Assembly of the State of Mississippi, in convention assembled, do ordain and enact that the State of Mississippi **shall be, from and after the passage of this act, a free, sovereign, and independent State, with all the rights and powers heretofore possessed as a sovereign member of the Union, among which is the **right to maintain and protect the institution of slavery**.”

*(Source: Mississippi Secession Convention Journal, 1861; reproduced in *The Documentary History of the Secession of Southern States*, Vol. 1, ed. William W. Freehling & John M. Coski, pp. 291‑295.)*
